title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: valentineTool package provides functions help analyze consumer spending trends Valentine’s Day. vignette demonstrates use plot_trends_custom() function visualize multiple spending categories single plot. plotting multiple lines, can better understand spending patterns different Valentine’s Day gifts evolved years.

title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: First, need load valentineTool package. also use dplyr data manipulation.
code: library(valentineTool) library(dplyr) ##  ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ##  ##     filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ##  ##     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)

title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: valentineTool package provides dataset called historical_spending. dataset contains information Valentine’s Day spending trends different categories 2010 2022.

title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: want plot spending trends Candy, Flowers, Jewelry time understand categories compare . plot_trends_custom() function allows us visualize multiple categories single plot.  plot, line represents spending trend different category. comparing trends, can see spending different gift categories evolved years. example, might notice spending jewelry increased significantly compared candy flowers.

title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: make plot informative, can customize adding title, changing colors, positioning legend.  customized plot, : Added Title: helps communicate key message plot. Changed Colors: assigned specific colors category better distinction. Adjusted Legend Position: Placing legend bottom helps make plot organized.
code: plot_trends_custom(historical_spending, c("Candy", "Flowers", "Jewelry")) +   labs(title = "Spending Trends for Candy, Flowers, and Jewelry",        x = "Year",        y = "Spending in USD") +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Candy" = "red", "Flowers" = "green", "Jewelry" = "blue")) +   theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +   theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Visualizing Multiple Spending Trends with valentineTool
text: plot_trends_custom() function powerful tool visualizing multiple consumer spending categories time. using , can easily compare trends draw insights changing consumer preferences Valentine’s Day. Customizing plot helps making visualizations appealing easier interpret. Feel free experiment categories dataset uncover insights Valentine’s Day spending trends!

what: Valentine's Day Consumer Trends Analysis Tool
title: Valentine's Day Consumer Trends Analysis Tool
text: goal valentineTool provide analysis tool Valentine’s Day consumer trends. package helps users visualize consumer spending years different categories candy, flowers, jewelry, . functions package particularly useful analysts, researchers, businesses looking understand changing consumer behavior Valentine’s Day.

title: Valentine's Day Consumer Trends Analysis Tool
text: can install development version valentineTool GitHub :
code: # Install remotes if not already installed install.packages("remotes")  # Install the package from GitHub remotes::install_github("ETC5523-2024/assignment-4-packages-and-shiny-apps-ChenghaoZeng")

title: Valentine's Day Consumer Trends Analysis Tool
text: basic example shows solve common problem: ## Main Components valentineTool Package historical_spending Dataset: package includes dataset (historical_spending) contains data consumer spending related Valentine’s Day various years. dataset includes categories like Candy, Flowers, Jewelry, GreetingCards, EveningOut, Clothing, GiftCards, allowing -depth analysis spending trends across different types gifts. Visualization Function: plot_trends_custom(data, y_vars): function plot multiple spending trends time. function allows users select one spending categories generate line plot visualize trends. Different colors assigned category make plot easy interpret. Filter Spending Data Year Range:filter_by_year(data, start_year, end_year). Launch Valentine’s Day Consumer Trends Shiny App: launch_valentine_app(). Package Documentation Examples README: README provides overview package, install , basic examples use features. also contains installation instructions using remotes::install_github() examples help users get started. Vignette:vignette provide -depth guide use package. include detailed analysis scenarios, step--step examples, real-world use cases. Function Documentation:function detailed documentation explains purpose function, parameters, example usage. Shiny App: Shiny app included package inst/shiny allows users interactively explore different spending trends.
code: library(valentineTool) library(ggplot2)  # Create the line plot for PercentCelebrating ggplot(historical_spending, aes(x = Year, y = PercentCelebrating)) +   geom_line(color = "blue") +                     labs(title = "Percent Celebrating Valentine's Day Over Time",        x = "Year",        y = "Percent Celebrating") +   theme_minimal()

what: Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Data from 2010 to 2022 — historical_spending
title: Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Data from 2010 to 2022 — historical_spending
text: dataset containing historical consumer spending trends Valentine's Day United States across multiple categories, years 2010 2022.

title: Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Data from 2010 to 2022 — historical_spending
Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Data from 2010 to 2022 — historical_spending
text: data frame 13 rows 10 columns: Year Year recorded spending (2010-2022). PercentCelebrating Percentage people celebrating Valentine's Day given year. PerPerson Average amount spent per person USD. Candy Average amount spending candy USD. Flowers Average amount spending flowers USD. Jewelry Average amount spending jewelry USD. GreetingCards Average amount spending greeting cards USD. EveningOut Average amount spending evening outings USD. Clothing Average amount spending clothing USD. GiftCards Average amount spending gift cards USD.

title: Valentine's Day Consumer Spending Data from 2010 to 2022 — historical_spending

Plot Multiple Consumer Spending Trends with Custom Colors — plot_trends_custom
text: data data frame containing historical spending data. y_vars vector strings representing columns plotted Y-axis.

title: Plot Multiple Consumer Spending Trends with Custom Colors — plot_trends_custom
text: ggplot object

title: Plot Multiple Consumer Spending Trends with Custom Colors — plot_trends_custom
code: # Load the valentineTool package library(valentineTool)  # Load example dataset provided in the package data("historical_spending")  # Plot trends for Candy, Flowers, and Jewelry over time plot_trends_custom(historical_spending, c("Candy", "Flowers", "Jewelry"))
